subject: Re: [junit] Re: Categories in JUnit4?
msgSnippet: ... You always find me... ... If functional tests take 10 hours, then is it really one application? I m imagining that in 10 hours we can run 5,000 functional
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On 11/27/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
> >
> > In a configuration that complex, I would probably not have enough
> > confidence to ship code without running every single test. If the system
> > is really that big, and test runs take hours, then I would immediately
> > evaluate the benefits of splitting that system into loosely coupled
> > parts and evolving them in separate source trees.
>
> You can run, but you can't hide :-)

You always find me...

> Eventually, any software that becomes reasonably complex takes time testing,
> and I don't think there is any way around that. My experiences range from
> small software (TestNG - 300 tests, less than 10 seconds to run them all) to
> fairly large ones, where functional tests takes anywhere between five and
> ten hours (yes, 5 and 10). Using groups in such systems is invaluable.

If functional tests take 10 hours, then is it really one application?
I'm imagining that in 10 hours we can run 5,000 functional tests, and it
seems to me that that's a large number for a system that can't
reasonably be modularized into a few small projects. I would have
probably started considering that after the tests started taking 30 minutes.

> Although I have to say that for such large scale software, the hurdle is
> usually much more the communication between the QA and the engineering teams
> than it is about test infrastructure, but every bit counts.

Indeed.

> Agree, that's why groups called "fast" and "slow" make much more sense than
> "unit" and "functional", in my opinion.

Absolutely. I tend to use "fast" and "slow", knowing that isolated
object tests tend to be fast by their very nature, and slow tests tend
to be integration/system/load/end-to-end.

> Fair point. It looks like in this particular case, your experience does not
> match mine and Jon's.

That'll happen.
